title: Ukraine to Legalize Crypto In 2025 Without Tax Exemptions: Report
body: Ukraine is taking a bold step towards becoming a crypto hub as it prepares to legalize cryptocurrency by the first quarter of 2025. According to reports, the move comes with a clear caveat: tax exemptions will not be part of the package. This development was revealed by Danylo Hetmantsev, Head of the Ukrainian Parliament Committee for Finances, Tax and Customs Policy, during the Domestic Investment Opportunities forum recently hosted by Ekonomichna Pravda. Crypto Legalisation Timeline and Legislative Progress Hetmantsev announced that a draft law, developed in close collaboration with the National Bank of Ukraine and the International Monetary Fund (IMF), is nearing completion. He mentioned that the draft is expected to be ready after the New Year, and the crypto legalization will be passed after that. This draft law builds on a milestone in November 2023, when Ukraine‚Äôs parliament introduced legislation on taxing virtual asset transactions. The passage of this new bill will mark the final step in creating a regulatory framework for cryptocurrencies in the country. Similarly, Russia recently introduced a new crypto bill that focuses on crypto transactions. The bill aims to regulate digital assets and ensure compliance with financial laws. If Ukraine legalizes crypto in 2025, it will join countries such as the United States, Canada, Japan, Germany, Australia, and Switzerland. These nations have embraced virtual assets and implemented rules to manage risks and ensure compliance with tax and financial laws. The Taxation Model: No Special Privileges While legalizing digital assets is a significant move, the absence of tax exemptions reflects a cautious and practical approach. According to Hetmantsev, profits from crypto will be taxed under the same model applied to securities. Taxes will only be levied when assets are converted into traditional currency. This cautious approach aligns with international best practices, ensuring digital assets do not create loopholes in Ukraine‚Äôs tax system. Many countries, including the U.S., the U.K., Canada, and Germany, have adopted a similarly cautious approach to the taxation of digital assets. Ukraine in the Crypto Space Ukraine has been a prominent player in the global crypto landscape, making consistent strides toward integrating digital assets into its economy. In 2022, the Ukrainian Parliament passed the ‚ÄúOn Virtual Assets‚Äù law , which provided a legal definition for cryptocurrencies and recognized them as an asset class. This law laid the groundwork for the current efforts toward full-scale legalization. Also, the Ministry of Digital Transformation has actively collaborated with international blockchain companies and tech giants to develop a robust digital economy. During the early days of the Russian invasion, Ukraine embraced crypto donations. This move showcased the practical utility of digital assets during crises. The initiative raised millions to support defense and humanitarian efforts. As the first quarter of 2025 approaches, all eyes will be on Ukraine as it navigates the challenges and opportunities of becoming a fully crypto-legal nation. title: Dogecoin Network Hit by Vulnerability, 69% of Nodes Crashed
body: A hacker exploited a major security vulnerability in the Dogecoin network on Dec. 12, crashing 69% of its active nodes. Andreas Kohl, co-founder of Bitcoin sidechain Sequentia, identified himself as the hacker in a post on X. Kohl said he used an old laptop in El Salvador to carry out the cyberattack. The Doge network had 647 active nodes before the attack, but only around 315 remained functional afterward, according to data from Blockchair . At the time of publishing, 376 are currently functional. This incident highlights the vulnerabilities in widely used blockchain networks like Dogecoin. The ability for a remote attacker to crash nearly 70% of the network's nodes with minimal effort raises concerns about the security of decentralized systems, experts said. title: Hacker Exploits Dogecoin (DOGE) Flaw, Causing 69% of Nodes To Crash
body: New data blockchain explorer Blockchair reveals that a hacker took advantage of an exploit in Dogecoin‚Äôs ( DOGE ) blockchain, causing the majority of its nodes to crash. Earlier this week, a Dogecoin monitoring platform noticed that the number of DOGE nodes dipped from 647 to just 205, a decrease of about 69%. ‚ÄúOur monitoring made us aware that the vulnerability appears to have been exploited, and almost 69% of the Dogecoin network has crashed. Blockchair shows the number of public nodes. Before, it was 647, and at the time of writing it is just 205.‚Äù However, according to Blockchair, some DOGE nodes have since recovered as there are currently 331 active nodes around the world at time of writing. In a recent thread on the social media platform X, Bitcoin ( BTC ) sidechain developer Andreas Kohl says that he was the one who took down most of the DOGE network using an old laptop. ‚ÄúI used a publicly disclosed vulnerability [by BTC developer Tobias Ruck] to take down 69% of the Dogecoin network from an old thinkpad in rural El Salvador.‚Äù According to Kohl, most DOGE users didn‚Äôt even notice . ‚ÄúOnly nodes that weren‚Äôt on the latest version were affected ‚Äì which was the majority of the network, excluding CEXs (centralized exchanges) and most other major custodians ‚Äì hence why most doge users never noticed, not that many understand self-custody.‚Äù News of the exploit had little impact on the price of DOGE as the meme asset is trading for $0.413 at time of writing, a 4.7% decrease during the last 24 hours. title: Google and Harvard debut dataset with 1m public domain books for AI training
body: Harvard University, in conjunction with Google, has released a dataset of a million public domain books to train the next generation of AI. The books span genres, languages, and authors such as Dickens, Dante, and Shakespeare which are no longer copyright protected because of their age. The new dataset initiative comes as AI training data is naturally pricey and best suited for tech firms with deep pockets. Harvard got financial backing from tech giants According to a TechCrunch article, the initiative is spearheaded by the Harvard‚Äôs Institutional Data Initiative (IDI). This initiative contains books derived from Google‚Äôs longstanding book-scanning project Google Books . Other books contained in the dataset include Czech math textbooks and Welsh pocket dictionaries. The university teased the IDI in March clearly stating its plans to create a ‚Äútrusted conduit for legal data for AI.‚Äù Since then, not much was heard from it until the formal launch on Thursday and tech giants Microsoft and OpenAI funded the project. The dataset is not a preserve of Silicon Valley alone but IDI has opened it to anyone, that is from research labs to AI startups that want to train their large language models. By opening the dataset to anyone, IDI executive director Greg Leppert said the dataset is meant to level the playing field, at a time when the cost of training AI remains high and prohibitive to smaller companies and making it preserve of those with huge budgets. Leppert added that the dataset is ‚Äúrigorously reviewed,‚Äù which according to Fudzilla presumably means someone checked to ensure that Bard was really gone and out of the way. The Harvard dataset will need more resources According to Leppert, who compared the dataset‚Äôs potential to Linux, the open source operating system, the success of the Harvard dataset will be hinged on a number of variables. Leppert said its success will require more resources, expertise, and a ‚Äúsprinkle of magic‚Äù from those same deep-pocketed corporations that the initiative is designed to challenge. The million books contained in the dataset were scanned as part of Google Books program. Fudzilla describes the initiative as a digital time capsule from when Google‚Äôs ambitions to scan every book seemed quirky rather than dystopian. However, Leppert is upbeat about the project‚Äôs potential uses, further suggesting it could a such a treasure trove helping train AI models for everyone from garage startups to the corporate conglomerates. While some have praised the initiative as a revolutionary leap forward in democratizing AI, Fudzilla opines that some might see this as a subtle means of ensuring that any ambitious upstart with a few terabytes of server space can now compete in a race to develop the next ChatGPT. However, they will need more resources to compete and make a dent in the market. ChatGPT launched in November 2022 to immediate success, which spurred the race for generative AI models across the globe. However, the development of these models has created a thirst for data to perfect them and this desire for more data has caused problems on how much information they can get, without stealing it. To date, publishers like the Wall Street Journal and the New York Times have sued OpenAI and Perplexity over using their data without permission. title: MicroStrategy wins Bitcoin miners‚Äô approval for convertible note strategy
body: Bitcoin miners are taking notes, literally, from MicroStrategy‚Äôs aggressive financial strategy. Riot Platforms and MARA Holdings are now following the playbook, issuing convertible notes to buy Bitcoin. Clearly, these guys are no longer satisfied with just validating transactions and earning rewards. Instead, they‚Äôre mimicking MicroStrategy (MSTR) CEO Michael Saylor‚Äôs tactic of turning corporate resources into a Bitcoin stockpile machine. Wall Street‚Äôs obsession with the skyrocketing MSTR‚Äîup over 600% this year‚Äîis impossible to ignore. Hedge funds are loving the opportunity, deploying arbitrage strategies that take advantage of Bitcoin‚Äôs infamous volatility. Miners can‚Äôt keep up with MicroStrategy‚Äôs pace Despite the hype, Riot and MARA aren‚Äôt seeing the same success as MicroStrategy. Since the software company started its Bitcoin-buying spree in 2020, Riot and MARA shares have underperformed. Both remain far below their 2021 highs. The April Bitcoin halving event didn‚Äôt help. It slashed the rewards miners earn for adding new blocks to the blockchain, putting a major dent in profits. Throw in increased competition, and miners are now fighting an uphill battle to stay relevant. Riot‚Äôs convertible notes have raised eyebrows though. The notes came with a 32.5% conversion premium, lower than MicroStrategy‚Äôs November issuance, which had a 55% premium. Riot is also facing pressure from activist investor Starboard Value, which recently took a stake in the company. Starboard is pushing the miner to shift some of its operations toward hyperscalers‚Äîlarge-scale data center users‚Äîrather than focusing solely on Bitcoin mining. Meanwhile, analysts are questioning the long-term viability of using convertible debt to stockpile Bitcoin. Stephen Glagola from JonesTrading has expressed doubts about this strategy, saying, ‚ÄúWe would prefer the company to increase BTC held per share organically with its mining operations.‚Äù Meanwhile, investment giant BlackRock is cautiously endorsing Bitcoin as part of diversified portfolios. The firm suggests investors allocate up to 2% to Bitcoin but only if they‚Äôre prepared to stomach its wild volatility. MicroStrategy on its way to Nasdaq 100, critics weigh in MicroStrategy is now eyeing a spot in the Nasdaq 100 Index, a move that could trigger massive passive inflows into its stock. Exchange-traded funds worth $451 billion track the index, and inclusion would mean huge stock purchases. But not everyone is sold on the idea. Critics argue that MicroStrategy‚Äôs reliance on Bitcoin makes it more of a financial entity than a technology company. Michael Lebowitz from RIA Advisors went as far as calling it ‚Äúessentially a dead company‚Äù without its Bitcoin holdings. Despite the criticisms, MicroStrategy has amassed a $98 billion market cap, largely due to its aggressive Bitcoin acquisitions. The company now holds over $40 billion in Bitcoin, but its core software business isn‚Äôt doing so hot. It reported a $340 million net loss in Q3 this year. Still, its Bitcoin-focused strategy has kept its stock soaring, even as skeptics question its sustainability. MicroStrategy has branded itself as a ‚ÄúBitcoin Treasury Company.‚Äù This identity could work in its favor for Nasdaq inclusion, as the index excludes financial companies. Its classification as a technology company by the Industry Classification Benchmark might be its saving grace. But Bloomberg Intelligence analyst James Seyffart has warned that a reclassification could be on the horizon, jeopardizing its eligibility. title: Ukraine To Legalize Crypto: Lawmakers Preparing Bill For Early 2025
body: As the market continues its massive rally, Ukrainian lawmakers are preparing to legalize crypto soon officially. Local reports revealed that the parliament is working on a draft law but is not considering tax exemptions for digital assets. Ukraine Prepares To Legalize Crypto During a ‚ÄúDomestic Investment Opportunities‚Äù forum, Danylo Hetmantsev, Head of the Ukrainian Parliament Committee for Finances, Tax and Customs Policy, revealed that Ukraine aims to legalize digital assets in the coming months. Hetmantsev stated that the parliament‚Äôs working group is working alongside the National Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) on a draft law to pass the legislation in early 2025, news media outlet Ukrainska Pravda reported : If we‚Äôre talking about cryptocurrency, the [parliament‚Äôs] working group is finalizing a draft law for its first reading. I believe the text, developed in collaboration with the National Bank and the IMF, will be ready after the New Year. We aim to pass this law and legalize cryptocurrency in the [2025‚Äôs] first quarter. The head of the Committee also noted that tax exemptions won‚Äôt be applied to digital assets. Instead, they plan to follow the model used for securities, meaning that profits will be taxed when the assets are converted into currency. Hetmantsev also explained that they will take a ‚Äúvery cautious approach to using cryptocurrencies for tax exemptions‚Äù after consulting with the IMF and European experts, ‚Äúas it could potentially facilitate tax evasion in traditional markets.‚Äù Ukraine‚Äôs Regulatory Landscape President Volodymyr Zelenskyy signed the ‚ÄúOn Virtual Assets‚Äù law in March 2022, setting in motion a legal framework for regulating the digital asset market in Ukraine. However, the law had not been implemented by early 2024, as it awaited the amendments to the country‚Äôs Tax Code. This resulted in the loss of millions in potential tax revenue, as the absence of crypto-related regulations meant that exchanges had no legal obligations to pay the Ukrainian authorities taxes for the revenue obtained from digital assets. In April, the IMF asked Ukraine to complete an update on its crypto legislation by the end of 2024. According to a Facebook post from Deputy Minister of Digital Transformation Oleksandr Bornyakov, the IMF noted that the lack of regulation of the new industry posed a threat to ‚Äúprice stability and efficiency of monetary transmission.‚Äù Bornyakov noted that the Ministry of Digital Transformation‚Äôs team had stressed the need to introduce state regulation in the crypto asset market, pointing to the two draft laws already registered for consideration in the parliament. Additionally, he highlighted that crypto legislation could have a positive financial impact on the country and boost Ukraine‚Äôs economic growth, emphasizing that prompt action would also strengthen international confidence in the country: In times of war, we must use the full range of opportunities and develop new sectors of the economy. Legalization of the crypto sector can have a powerful economic effect, generating a turnover of billions of hryvnias. It‚Äôs worth noting that Ukraine has received significant aid from the global community through crypto donations since Russia‚Äôs invasion started in February 2022, with figures like Vitalik Buterin and Justin Sun donating millions of digital assets.

title: Nuclear energy is inevitable as AI electricity demand continues to grow, Japan‚Äôs top utility advisor predicts
body: The rapid growth of artificial intelligence globally will cause a surge in electricity demands that will initially be met by fossil fuels, at least until nuclear power becomes the obvious solution, according to Dale Klein, former chairman of the US Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Klein, who is currently serving as the chairman of the nuclear reform monitoring committee for Tokyo Electric Power Co. (TEPCO), said nuclear energy is essential for long-term sustainability. However, he noted that these power sources would need time to scale up their infrastructure. Meeting immediate energy demands As data centers, the backbone of artificial intelligence operations, are built in countries like Japan and the US, natural gases have become necessities to meet surging power demands. Data centers are heavily reliant on energy, and the global boom of AI is pushing power grids to their limits. Natural gas is the most commonly used fuel in the US, and it is expected to account for up to 60% of new-generation projects in the coming years. While natural gas is cleaner than coal, this reliance on natural gases comes with its own set of environmental concerns, particularly related to methane emissions and long-term carbon commitments. In other places, fossil fuels are an immediate solution to the rising electricity demand brought on by the rapid expansion of artificial intelligence technology. However, Klein sees these fossil fuel power sources as short-term solutions, especially because existing renewable energy and nuclear capabilities cannot be scaled up quickly enough to meet the demand. The timeline for nuclear energy According to Klein, gas will be used to assuage the boom in energy demand from AI until small modular reactors and larger plants can be built to enable nuclear energy to take its place. Major tech companies like Google, Microsoft, and Meta have invested in nuclear solutions to power their AI operations. Meta recently announced plans to partner with developers for nuclear energy projects capable of delivering up to 4 gigawatts of power by the early 2030s. Similarly, Microsoft has secured nuclear power commitments, including a deal to purchase energy from the Three Mile Island nuclear plant. Meanwhile, Google is investing in small modular reactors (SMRs) However, their methods cannot be applied universally or immediately. ‚Äú We just cannot meet this big demand for these data centers without nuclear plants if we‚Äôre going to maintain a reduction in greenhouse gases,‚Äù Klein told Bloomberg . Nuclear energy remains a sensitive topic in Japan due to the 2011 Fukushima disaster. The country has also been witnessing a downtrend in energy demands due to depopulation. However, people familiar with the problem have suggested that the situation can be turned around by building more data centers and semiconductor plants.
